hook.text: A Roman father had the legal right to sell, abandon, or even kill his own children. Few did. But he could.

buildup.text: Patria potestas gave the father absolute authority over every family member, including adult children.

discovery.text: In practice, Roman fathers were often affectionate. Cicero's letters to his daughter are full of tenderness.

twist.text: The law reflected power structure, not daily reality. Most Roman parents loved their children deeply.

climax.text: Roman childhood shows how legal frameworks and emotional realities can be wildly different.

punchline.text: Harsh laws couldn't erase parental love â€” only failed to protect it.

quiz.question: What was patria potestas in ancient Rome?
options: The father's absolute legal authority over family members
